segments.text: Calling in tactical air support and assisting the forward air controller who was airborne also in his little bird dog airplane and getting fire in on the enemy and at the same time I'd call for Smokey
Smokey is a fella in an old DC-3 that comes in and drops flares for you.
So you can see it light up the area.
We're talking about 2 or 3 in the morning?
Oh, we're talking about now it's 2 o'clock, 3 o'clock, 4 o'clock.
So we're beating them back pretty heavily.
and have just kept them out of that troop of cavalry.
I mean, 1900 against 125, you know, that's a hellacious odds.
So we had been doing very well.
And in the meantime, the battalion commander

A lieutenant colonel who had come up from the ranks and was out of World War II, believe it or not he was a private in the reconnaissance troop of the 1st Division during World War II as a private about 16 years old and now here he is a lieutenant colonel here commanding the 5th Cavalry of the 9th Division which is a reconnaissance squadron.
And here they are attached to the big red one.
And he said he wanted to get in the fire base with the captain.
I said, well, you're going to have to fight your way in there and I'll help you get in.
He said, I'm going to take two of my track vehicles, M-113 personnel carrier track vehicles, and said, we're going to shoot our way through.
And I said,
Fine, because I said if his radio goes down I need all the radios that I can get in there that I can talk to so that we can direct this battle properly.
One of his vehicles was knocked out and he got out under fire and backed up his van.
His radio operator was killed and the commander of that vehicle was killed.
He got out himself personally and
and hooked up his vehicle, another 113 personnel carrier, command type vehicle, to the vehicle that had been destroyed and drug it into the perimeter.
He won, he was presented Distinguished Service Cross for this action,

To make a long story short, I knew that it was 4 o'clock in the morning, 4.30 in the morning, and I alerted everyone to the fact that I felt that that regiment, their losses being very heavy, would attempt another assault at about 5 o'clock in the morning.
And that I wanted the...
The...

In secure, with secure communications, I talked to the commander on the ground, now Lieutenant Colonel Haphazard, and I said, I want at 5.15 or earlier, depending on when this last and final assault comes, I want

every vehicle turn every vehicle that's capable of turning on its lights to turn them on as soon as that assault occurs and uh this is kind of like exposing yourself to everything in their eyes they said oh i said that's exactly the way i want it
I had 15 sorties of TAC air stacked up, 15 airplanes stacked up waiting.
I had the artillery all cocked and primed although they were still shooting at designated targets.
Well sure enough at about
0510 in the morning a fire began to come in, the intensity of the fire began to come in.
At 0515 the commies got up and started to move and I started peeling off those fighter bombers with CBU and napalm and we murdered them.
And when it was all over with and daylight came we had three dead cavalrymen and eleven slightly wounded.
Now there's no 125 of anybody's soldiers in anybody's army in the world can stand up to 1,900 soldiers and only lose three men and 11 wounded
Five hours plus of battle, of intense battle, except the United States Army soldiers supported by the United States Air Force.
That's the only 125 little guys in the world that can do that sort of job.
And the next day the enemy, how many they drug off, we don't know, but they left 499 dead on the battlefield, which is a sacred sin and a dishonor to the bastards.
But that's what firepower will do.
Properly directed by somebody that knows what the hell he's doing.
And the continuous firepower on the enemy
Then on April 1st at a place called AP, A-P, capital G-U, the 26th Infantry was commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Alexander M. Haig, Jr. And they were air assaulted in the afternoon of March 31st.
into this area, which was at one time some 20 years ago before the communists uprooted the civilian populace there and murdered them all and took over the country, was a small village.
But the communists had killed everyone and taken over themselves.
And this was about two miles from the Cambodian border in Tainan province.
And we were operating in that area.

And Lieutenant Colonel Haig had air assaulted into this area with the 1st Battalion of 26th Infantry in the afternoon and immediately sent out his reconnaissance platoon commanded by Lieutenant Hill to do the necessary scout and reconnaissance while his battalion dug in.
They were going to spend the night there and attack from there the next day.
along the Cambodian border.
The reconnaissance platoon had not moved more than 300 meters from the perimeter that the former Secretary of State, Alexander Haig, then Lieutenant Colonel, was digging himself in on the perimeter.
When Lieutenant Hill bumped into a heavy formation, he was killed along with two others.
And Lieutenant Colonel Haig in a H-13 Bell helicopter, which is almost nothing, was up over those men, received intense fire, was shot down, and helicopter fell.
and he and the pilot got away from him before he burned and he proceeded on foot to get with that recon platoon and remove the wounded and his dead Lieutenant Hill.
As a result of that action that afternoon and I personally observed it and was there
I recommended Lieutenant Colonel Haig for the Distinguished Flying Cross and for his ground actions and that afternoon and the next day the Distinguished Service Cross.
The night
was settling and wore on and at 0530 in the morning his battalion was hit by 400 plus rounds of heavy mortar fire.
I immediately went to the scene in my command helicopter
um believing in firepower the artillery had been placed that day and in their early hours of the evening to fire and support the division's operations the next day along the cambodian border william
immediately, Colonel Haig immediately called for artillery fire for which he received instantaneously and for tactical air support.
At 537 the first, and this is significant now, at 537 in the morning the first tactical air arrived.
Remember the mortars came in at 5.30.
That's very significant because most people don't know how to use tactical air.
I'd say one out of every 400,000 in the Army, that means today they listen to people that know how to use tactical air.
I'm talking about officer or enlisted men.
That's every experience.
Yeah, they don't know anything about it.
Why is that?
They've never experienced it, and they don't know how to set it up.
You see, if you want to attack air early in the target, what you do is pre-plan the missions to be delivered sometime on your targets.
You pre-plan missions during the night at the point in time in which you expect the enemy to attack.

I always expected the enemy to attack at 5 30 in the morning and at midnight so I'd say to the Air Force I want my pre-planned missions on targets on known targets that I want bombed during the night and struck during the night I want those missions those sorties to be delivered
From 11.30 until 1 o'clock and from 5 o'clock until 6 o'clock in the morning.
Okay, they're up.
They're loaded.
They're in the process of delivering them.
Then when the enemy strikes, you divert those that are airborne and go there immediately.
Instead of waiting to wake up a pilot and to load up a ship and wait for that and while you get eat up by the enemy.
So it all depends on how professional you are about how you get on with getting your job done.
Well, that's the way to do it.
And that's the way it was done in the First Division.
So between 0537 and 958 the next morning when the enemy decided they didn't want anymore,
We set probably a world record.

We put in 133 sorties attack air and fired more than 15,000 rounds of 155, 105, and 8-inch artillery on the 271 Regiment and the 1st Battalion of the 1st NVA Regiment, which totaled about 2,800, 2,900 strength.
Again, 28, 2900 against about 500 was the strength of Colonel Hegg's battalion, except they concentrated only against B and C Company.
A Company, we took its ammunition and gave it to B and C Company during the night.
Colonel Hegg did that.
A company wasn't even scratched by this entire reinforced regiment.
And I want to tell you that we tore those people to shreds.
They left more than 600 dead.
And we had 37 killed and wounded.
And as a result of that action,
and what he had done before, I recommended Lieutenant Colonel Haig for the Distinguished Service Cross, which he has.
Again, a phenomenal action of American soldier and know-how against extreme unheard of odds.
six to one.
And when you start looking at how many was in action, it's probably ten to one because they only hit elements of two of the companies in the perimeter, two of the rifle companies in the perimeter.
There are two examples of

Now, the Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, General Bruce Palmer, who was in Vietnam at the time as a Lieutenant General, he felt that the action of General Haig and his, in that particular battle, would probably go down in history as the greatest battle at up to that point in time in Vietnam.
No kidding?
Yes, it was really a significant showing on the part of
American know-how against the Communists.
And again, as an action of the First Division.
I went home in the late May.
The brigade commander was wounded that day.
who the commander in which Colonel Hegg's 26th Infantry was assigned to.
And after that battle, Colonel Hegg became their brigade commander.
From there he was selected to go to West Point as a regimental
tactical, regimental tactical commander with one regiment of cadets.
I came back to the United States and we were having severe problems with the Congress on the bad results of the M16 rifle, on the poor results of the multi-fuel engine
There's some 11,000 multi-fuel engines made by Continental Motors in Muskegon that had performed so poorly that 11,000 of them are laying over there in Korea.
So that's bad.
Congress is raising hell and rightfully so about this.
And then there was a push to get a light vehicle called the M551 with a Sheridan missile system.
General Westmoreland was hollering for it.

Chief of Staff of the Army said, I'd like for you to go to Aberdeen Proving Grounds and put some combat experience into testing of this equipment because I'm tired of the Congress beating us to death on the inadequacies of this equipment.
and said, I feel it's because we're not testing it properly before we go to the field.

I rendered a report within six months to the Chief of Staff of the Army that it was not the testing, but it was the insistence on getting the stuff into the field before it was ready as a result of a Vietnamese conflict.
And I said, leave the people alone and let them test it properly before you introduce it into the field.
At about that time, Detroit blew up.
Washington, D.C. blew up.
Newark, New Jersey blew up.
Disaster.
Democracy creating anarchy.
Anarchy within democracy.
So you question, is democracy the right way to go or not?
We created it.
anarchy here.
You're destroying the damn country.
You're blowing up banks, churches, public buildings, schools.
What in the hell is democracy doing for the American people?
This is displaying the world and particularly the communists who are exploiting it that democracy is a total damn failure.
So
In such instances, as you know, under the Constitution, it provided national guard for the state's forces and militia to assist the governor in maintaining internal law and order.
And in each instance, there were total failures.
Failure in Detroit, failure in Newark, failure in Washington, D.C. And regular forces, active duty forces, were called in.
help stop those riotous situations and this is a embarrassment to the United States people in the throughout the world shining example of what must not happen total anarchy so
President Lyndon B. Johnson asked the former governor of Ohio to set up a commission to look at what in the name of God is going on in this country.
I can't remember the name of the former governor.
He was one that had some strength.

some criticism up there you know how he's doing business and Kinder I can't remember now what his name was but anyway it finally boiled down to me being pulled out of pulled out of Aberdeen Proving Grounds testing business by the chief of staff the army to go do a thorough investigation
of the failures in Detroit, Washington, D.C., and Newark of the National Guard.
No kidding.
Why do you think that they picked you?
Because of your experience with the reserves before?
I guess so.
So it's kind of more or less a chief of staff, the Army presidential, president, joint selectee to go do this.
So I put together a team of about 20 officers, took a special mission aircraft, and between July and February of the next year, I visited 90% of the states, and particularly concentrated on

what had gone wrong in Detroit, and what had gone wrong in Newark, and what had gone wrong in Washington, D.C. And it came up with what was known as the Hollingsworth Report, which was very, very critical of the inadequacies of the Reserve and the National Guard.
Do you have a copy of that?
All the copies I have of those are in Washington, D.C. What did it say?

It said that we don't have, if we can't control internal security of our country, how do you expect these forces in a time of war to be of any help to the external threat if you can't even handle the internal threat?
It sent forth some 50 recommendations to get ourselves sorted out, of which I think there was final approval on about 48 of them.
Really?
Yes.
Establish proper schooling, clean out people, get rid of the dead wood, properly training, properly equipping people,

primarily to reinforce and select and train leadership in the National Guard and I did not exclude the Reserves because I took advantage of the fact to look at the Reserves also because they were just as lousy as the Guard in many instances.
Totally.
You don't have to look at the Cuban call up and then see how lousy that is.
And then to go have your country collapse and the guard and the states and governors are calling for active duty forces, 82nd Airborne and others to come put the thing in order.
You don't have to be a blind man.
You don't have to
A third grader can see that.
Sure.
That you've got disaster on your hands.
And I think that report went a long ways to alerting everybody to the fact that you don't have anything out here.
You're just fooling yourself.
Again, this is a leniency.
They have fluency.
The lack of discipline amongst the people.
And we have some real failures.
We have some real failings amongst ourselves, you know.
And unfortunately in our country, we can't recognize our own inadequacies.
Oftentimes.
Most of the times you cannot.
And then when you do, you don't want to accept it.
This is the reason why one of the most worrisome things to me in the defense of this country is whether the political elements from the President to the Congress

will accept the cold hard facts of a communist threat and do something about it or they'll try to pass information off so that they don't believe it and then this country get the biggest shock of its life and lose the whole damn show because of politics
and weak leadership, not willing to accept the cold, hard facts of life.
So, you know, to have a good intelligence collecting capability is one thing, and to disseminate it to the right people is another thing.
But then to get those that it's disseminated to to face the real world and take some action,
where it needs to be, that's another thing.
And it takes a lot of backbone.
It takes a lot of courage.
It takes a lot of know-how.
It takes a lot of professionalism to stand up and say, by God, I was wrong.
We did not properly support our military here with what they need to do the job with.
And now the enemy is just kind of driving us up the damn wall.
You see?
And this is the most worrisome thing.
It's like, for example, I'll give you a good example of what I'm talking about.
The most warning that you'll probably receive
of attacks against NATO in Central Europe by the Warsaw Pact will probably be 48 hours.
Now, in order to prepare yourself for that sort of attack, it costs a lot of money.
Mr. Reagan is the only one that's been able to face up to that because it costs a lot of money to prepare yourself against that.

When you look at the real world, you're only going to have about 24 hours because in the NATO alliance, 15 member nations have to get together and spend 24 hours making a determination on whether or not these indicators that there will be an attack in 48 hours are really true or not.
And then you leave yourself only 24 hours to respond.
And it takes us three days or more to reinforce our air capability, and the Army doesn't get any assistance for ten days or more, because there's no air left.
And when I took command of the Warsaw Pact in 1976, in the Hollingsworth study now of NATO,
for the Secretary of the Army and for the Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, a joint requirement from those two to me.
I took the Ruhr in 72 hours.
And where is the United States in 72 hours?
They don't even have all their air over there yet.
And when you take the Ruhr in Germany,
You've got the heart of it, it's all over with.
Soviets playing around with marching to Antwerp in seven days.
I'd relieve the damn Soviet commander that took that long to get to Antwerp.
Hell, he couldn't work for me, but he's too damn slow.
You can do it, I can take their forces and do it quicker than that.
So if I can do that, you've got to give them credit for being able to do it.
So then you now get moving on what's necessary in order to avoid that sort of thing.
What did President Johnson say about your report, Hollinsworth report?
Oh, you mean we're going back now?
We're going back to the 1968 period?
I don't know what he said.
Did he read it?
The National Security Council was briefed.
And whether they briefed the president or not, I don't know.
I imagine that they did.
Because he was an instigator of it coming off.
And he was quite right.
If the National Guard can't do this thing, maybe we need more active duty forces.
Maybe we don't need a National Guard.
But that's not the case.
We do need a National Guard.
for internal security and to support the governor and the state police and the state municipal police in the case of disasters of any kind.
And secondly, to be prepared to accept a role in support of the active forces wherever they need to be in the world.
They've got to play an important role.
But by God, they've got to be prepared and ready to do something.
Did you meet LBJ?
Oh, yes.
When?
back in 1953, back when he was in the Senate.
Oh yeah, many times.
He and Lady Bird both.
What was your impression?
First-class politician of the highest order and who got things done through the political process.
Very effective.
No question about it.
Sam Rayburn was even far superior to him, who was Speaker of the House.
Now that, Rayburn Johnson was the old political regime in which Tip O'Neill is still one of.
And it's kind of dying out to a degree.
isn't so much as it used to be.
They don't have so much power as they used to have.
Now, at the end of this report then you were sent to Fort Jackson in South Carolina.
Yes, I was called in and said we have a major general down there training infantrymen for combat who is practicing on-the-job retirement.
What a way to put it, on the job retirement.
Yeah.
And go down there as a deputy and prepared to take over this thing.
That's all there was to it.
And I did that.
On the job retirement.
That's pretty good.
So he was sleeping.
Yes, very much so.
And it was at...
at that time that you got your second star.
Yes, that's right.
My second star, and I then went to take over U.S. Army Alaska.
Right, but at Port Jackson were you training men for Vietnam?
Yes, during my time there I trained a quarter of a million, about, we trained about as I think about 125 to 150,000 a year, combat infantrymen.
And I had a chance to study all these people, some of them were volunteers, most of them were draftees.

And I had some very revealing, some very interesting facts came from that and testing and watching these men and taking necessary information and analyzing and looking at where people had been and what they were and so on and so forth.
And I found a very disturbing situation that 22% of the high school diploma holders could not pass a fifth grade reading and writing.
22% of the high school diploma holders, graduates, that I received could not pass a fifth grade reading and writing and arithmetic.
And I thought this is the damnedest indictment against our
public and private educational system again it led me to say what in the name of God is this country doing to itself and I learned a new term for the first time social promotion

if the guy's a total failure in the first grade after he's been there maybe the second time if you've got guts enough to do it give him a social promotion to the second grade because he's getting too big in size for or she for the rest of the little fellas and you just go ahead and do that right through on out the 12th grade and I think this is the most damaging
thing to the American system.
It's kind of like Governor Clements here trying to focus in on getting our education system to stand up with some guts and teach these people
how to read and write our youth.
And I think they deserve that.
I found a percentage of one-year and two-year college students, a small percentage of those who could not pass the fifth grade comprehensive of one-year and two-year college levels at that time.

When you were in command there, this was right after the Tet Offensive in January of 1968, and after that time there was a growing distaste for the war in Vietnam, and of course we were still building our number of our troop strength, and it didn't come to half our 500
60,000 until 1969 so we were still building and so we were drafting more.

A lot has been said about the quality of these men who were going over to Vietnam and we're going to talk about the quality of the soldiers that you had in Vietnam later but right now what about the quality of these recruits, these draftees?
These draftees were a cross-section of the eastern
part of the United States out to include Ohio, West Virginia, Tennessee, and generally speaking the ones I had at Fort Jackson with some exceptions where you'd have an overflow in some other place.
Most of them were from east of the Mississippi, although you would get some maybe a hundred or two hundred from here from west of the Mississippi, but most of them were east of the Mississippi.
I thought they represented a cross-section of the United States.
I thought that I was getting more of the communist inspired types than I would expect as my share.
As a matter of fact,
I did have five commies try to create a disturbance one evening in one of my brigades.
Tell me about it.
And I locked them up.
I threw them in jail.
Well, tell me about it.
What did they try to do, more specifically?
Well, they tried to, they were in the Did they admit that they were commies?
Oh, they were Associates Worker Party guys and also mousy tongue types out of Chicago.
They were heavily supported by the ACLU and the Communist parties in the United States out of Washington, D.C. Marcus Lennon group out of Washington, D.C.
Mousetongues out of Chicago, the same types that created the disturbance at Kent State and were all buried back in Chicago when that one blew, remember?
Well, I had put the word out that I wouldn't tolerate any of this crap, communist crap.
It wasn't going to happen, by God, and that
No Jane Fondas are going to visit.
She had been on several Army posts and tried to get along, but I said, in one Army post, that the Communist-inspired elements are not going to interfere with.
And I said, there isn't any damn question about this.
And I wanted it to be known publicly, and it wasn't known publicly.
Well, somehow or another, five of these guys showed up there
Were they recruits or were they just?
They were in advance training.

They had created disturbances at other places and instead of the Army taking action, you had some weak goddamn commanders as you have in all walks of life that were more interested in themselves and weren't interested in creating any, taking any action to do something, you know, when action was required.
So they keep passing these jokers along.
Instead of killing the goddamn snake, you just chase him off out of this bunch of woods into another one, you see.
I like to kill a son of a bitch when you've got a goddamn rattlesnake.
Don't chase him over another guy's yard.
So they chased about five of them into my yard, and that's where they made their damn mistake.
What'd they do?

Well, they tried to create a revolt and revolution one evening down between the two barracks out making speeches, you know, about about how bad Vietnam was and this is not a democracy and you got your rights and this that and the other and all this horseshit and so I just sent the MPs down and I said lock those communist bastards up which they did and then I
started action to court-martial them and press got in the act.
ACLU got in the act.
Their ACLU lawyer, we were denying their rights and so on and so forth.
Make a long story short, I court-martialed them in a closed court and the New York Times came down and
wanting to attend the trial.

I said, apparently you people are stupider than I think you are, or maybe you're in the same category as these fellows, but since you can't read and write, maybe I better tell you that I said the court was closed.
And they're not going to be tried in a newspaper.
They're going to be tried in a legal court.
That's what I told the goddamn reporter from New York Times.
He went back to Washington and went up to see a guy named Laird, who was a politician, Secretary of Defense.
And Laird sent him down to the PIO, the Public Information Officer, Assistant Secretary, I think his name was Ross.
And then Ross, he calls the Army, and then the Army...
